column2: Program/application/module listings are held in a secure environment

Source code on portable systems such as laptops must be protected with whole disk encryption.

column1: Technology Product Owner: Error messages are configured not to contain sensitive information, including system details,  account information or cryptographic information.

column2: Do not disclose sensitive information in error responses, including system details, session identifiers or account information
Use error handlers that do not display debugging or stack trace information
Implement generic error messages and use custom error pages
The application should handle errors and not rely on the server configuration
Properly free allocated memory when error conditions occur
Error handling logic associated with security controls should deny access by default

column1: Technology Product Owner: Security event logs are created in line with the organisation's Logging and Monitoring standard. Security events are logged to identify anomalies or suspicious activity or potential security incidents. Logging requirement are determined in conjunction with the Office of the Chief Security Officer.

column2: The following security events are logged and reviewed to identify anomalies or suspicious activity or potential security incidents

column1: - Changes to the configuration of an IT security system or service
- Changes to the secure configuration of an IT system or service
- Cessation of operation of an IT security system or service
- Creation, modification, or deletion of operating system log files

column2: All event logging meets the following minimum requirements:

column1: i. All security events (as defined in the as prescribed in the Cyber Threat Management Standard) are logged, and, where the event relates to a particular account, is traceable to a unique individual.
ii. The system transmits the log to the applicable log management system, and not delete the local copy of the log until receipt has been confirmed.
iii. Log entries, once created, must be read only.  Privileged accounts must not be able to modify logs of their own actions.
iv. Access to modify or delete log files and data must be subject to a dual control process.
v. Log files and data are protected from unauthorised modification and deletion in transit and in storage.
vi. The reviewer doesn't hold a privileged account on the system in question.

column2: The ability to change the standard, centralised and accurate source of UTC time used by logging services is restricted
The following items captured in event logs are removed, masked, sanitised, hashed or encrypted depending on usage requirements:

column1: - sensitive personal data and forms of personally identifiable information (PII)
- encryption keys and other master secrets
- bank account or payment card holder data
- data of a higher security classification than the logging system is allowed to store
- information which a user has not consented to, or has opted out of, being collected.

column2: Requirements for security event logging, monitoring (including real-time monitoring), reviewing, alerting, retention and archiving is determined in conjunction with the Application Owner / System Owner. Security Monitoring and alerting is conducted 24 x 7 x 365
Staff (employees and contractors) activity on HVTs, MVEs, and CRITINF is constantly monitored subject to any legal and regulatory restrictions

column1: Technology Product Owner: Applications are deployed using a standard build configuration

column2: The application configuration build standard is defined and tested to comply with all applicable requirements.
All default accounts are disabled or passwords changed to strong passwords/phrases as prescribed in the Logical Access Management Standard
Ensure servers, frameworks and system components are running the latest approved version
Ensure servers, frameworks and system components have all patches issued for the version in use
Web-servers must be configured to turn off dir­ectory listings
Restrict the web-server, process and service accounts to the least privileges possible
When exceptions occur, fail securely
Remove all unnecessary functionality and files
Remove test code or any functionality not intended for production, prior to deployment

For web applications, prevent disclosure of your directory structure in the robots.txt file by placing directories not intended for public indexing into an isolated parent directory. Then Disallow"" that entire parent directory in the robots.txt file rather than disallowing each individual directory""
For web applications, define which HTTP methods Get or Post, the application will support and whether it will be handled differently in different pages in the application
For web applications, disable unnecessary HTTP methods, such as WebDAV extensions. If an extended HTTP method that supports file handling is required, utilize a GIS approved authentication mechanism

For web applications, if the webserver handles both HTTP 1.0 and 1.1, ensure that both are configured in a similar manner or insure that you understand any difference that may exist (e.g. handling of extended HTTP methods)
For web applications, remove unnecessary information from HTTP response headers related to the OS, web-server version and application frameworks
The security configuration store for the application should be exportable in a human readable form to support auditing

column1: Technology Product Owner: A file management system to govern the security of files such as data files, configuration and log files has been implemented

column2: Access to configuration files, data files and log files should be restricted to the applications that require access and users of the application should not have direct access to these files
Configuration files and log files should not contain passwords and other sensitive information
Do not pass user supplied data directly to any dynamically included function
Require authentication before allowing a file to be uploaded
Turn off execution privileges on file upload directories

When referencing existing files, use a white list of allowed file names and types. Validate the value of the parameter being passed and if it does not match one of the expected values, either reject it or use a hard coded default file value for the content instead
Do not pass user supplied data into a dynamic redirect. If this must be allowed, then the redirect should accept only validated, relative path URLs or URIs
Never send the absolute system file path to the client
Ensure application files and resources are read-only and are aligned to defined trust models
Scan external (i.e. from external to the organisation) user uploaded files for viruses and malware
Do not pass directory or file paths, use index values mapped to pre-defined list of paths
Limitations are placed on the type of files that can be uploaded such that only those types that are needed for business purposes are permitted
File headers, and not just file type or extension alone, are checked to ensure uploaded files are the expected type
Files are not stored in the same location as the application, but instead stored in a separate directory or in a separate data server such as a content server or a database server
The upload of any files that can be interpreted by the application is prevented  by including file check mechanism during upload
Secret information is stored encrypted in compliance with the organisation's cryptographic standards

column1: Technology Product Owner: Additional secure coding practices

column2: Utilize task specific built-in services and APIs to conduct operating system tasks. Do not allow the application to issue commands directly to the Operating System, especially through the use of application initiated command shells
Utilize locking to prevent multiple simultaneous requests or use a synchronization mechanism to prevent race conditions
Explicitly initialize all your variables and other data stores, either during declaration or just before the first usage
In cases where the application must run with elevated privileges, raise privileges; within the runtime environment; should do so as late as possible, and drop them as soon as possible
All third party dependencies (e.g. source code, applications and libraries) must be evaluated for security vulnerabilities before being deployed in production
Use tested and approved managed code rather than creating new unmanaged code for common tasks
Use checksums or hashes to verify the integrity of interpreted code, libraries, executables, and configuration files

Avoid calculation errors by understanding your programming language's underlying representation and how it interacts with numeric calculation. Pay close attention to byte size discrepancies, precision, signed/unsigned distinctions, truncation, conversion and casting between types, not-a-number"" calculations
Debug code must not be promoted into production except during diagnostic efforts undertaken through normal change management channels.

column1: If a personal data inventory does not currently exist for this Business Unit a new inventory must be created. Technology Product Owner: Data validation controls (type range and content checks) are implemented within applications

column2: There should be a centralized input validation routine for the application
Determine if the system supports UTF-8 extended character sets and if so, validate after UTF-8 decoding is completed
Validate all input against a white"" list of allowed characters
Sensitive operations (such as transactions) must not be replayable. The anti-replay mechanisms provided by SSL are not sufficient to meet this control as they only apply at the network level.
Identify all data sources and classify them into trusted and untrusted. Validate all data from untrusted Sources
Specify proper character sets, such as UTF-8, for all sources of input
Encode data to a common character set before validating (Canonicalize)
All validation failures should result in input rejection

Validate all client provided data before processing, including all parameters, URLs and HTTP header content (e.g. Cookie names and values). Be sure to include automated post backs from JavaScript, Flash or other embedded code
Verify that header values in both requests and responses contain only characters from defined character sets.
Validate data from redirects (An attacker may submit malicious content directly to the target of the redirect, thus circumventing application logic and any validation performed before the redirect)
Validate for expected data types
Validate data range
Validate data length
Validate input information for boundary values where applicable (e.g. input for dates do not have 13th months)

Failed secure connections should not fall back to an insecure connection
Utilize secure connections for all content requiring authenticated access
Specify character encodings for all connections
All applications accessible by users/systems only inside the bank should encrypt network communication with the latest secure communication protocol, as per the Organisation's cryptographic standards

AS-18: Application Data and Memory Management,story,*Narrative*
Technology Product Owner: Application should enable secure storage and usage of data and memory

column2: Implement least privilege; restrict access rights to only the functionality, data and system information that is required to perform the relevant tasks
Protect all cached or temporary copies of sensitive data stored on the server from unauthorized access and purge those temporary working files a soon as they are no longer required.

Do not store passwords, connection strings or other sensitive information in clear text or in any non-cryptographically secure manner on the client or server side. Remove comments in API accessible production code that may reveal backend system or other sensitive information
Remove unnecessary application and system documentation from production environment as this can reveal useful information to attackers
The application should support the removal of sensitive data when that data is no longer required. (E.g. personal information or certain financial data)
Implement appropriate access controls for sensitive data stored on the server. This includes cached data, temporary files and data that should be accessible only by specific system users.
Utilize input and output control for un-trusted data

Ensure that the buffer is as large as specified When using functions that accept a number of bytes to copy, such as strncpy(), be aware that if the destination buffer size is equal to the source buffer size, it may not NULL-terminate the string
Check buffer boundaries if calling the function in a loop and make sure there is no danger of writing past the allocated space
Truncate all input strings to a known-valid length for your application before passing them to the copy and concatenation functions
Properly free allocated memory upon the completion of functions and at all exit points

Use non-executable stacks (Hardware features such as the NX bit) when available. Executable space protection is the marking of memory regions as non-executable, such that an attempt to execute machine code in these regions will cause an exception
Avoid the use of functions such as printf, strcat, strcpy which are difficult to use securely where alternative safer functions are available.

column2: Turn off all unnecessary database functionality (e.g. Unnecessary stored procedures or services, utility packages, install only the minimum set of features and options required (surface area reduction))
The application should connect to the database with different credentials for every trust distinction/authorised access rights (e.g., user, read-only user, guest, administrators)
Use strongly typed parameterized queries
Utilize input validation and output encoding and be sure to address meta characters. If these fail, do not run the database command
Ensure that variables are strongly typed
The application should use the lowest possible level of privilege when accessing the database
Use secure credentials for database access
Connection strings should not be hard coded within the application. Connection strings should be stored in a separate configuration file on a trusted system and they should be encrypted.
Use stored procedures to abstract data access and allow for the removal of permissions to the base tables in the database
Close the connection to the database as soon as possible

column1: Product Owner: Measures have been employed in alignment with the relevant policies and standards, business need and applicable legislation and regulations to ensure the management of records throughout their lifecycle - creation, capturing, maintenance/retention, storage, destruction and retrieval

column2: Detailed audit logging is enforced for secret and confidential records
All cached or temporary copies of secret/confidential records are purged when they are no longer required
Relevant records are retained in accordance with records retention schedule(s) aligned to legislation and/or business requirement

Relevant records are destroyed securely (based on the classification of the record) within twelve months of the retention expiry date, except where a disposal hold notice applies. Relevant records eligible for destruction that have been subject to a disposal hold notice must be destroyed within twelve months of the applicable disposal hold(s) notice being lifted.
All records covered by a disposal hold notice are identified, located, and withheld from destruction in accordance with the requirements of the disposal hold notice.
Business-as-usual retention periods are reapplied to the relevant records, within 12 months of legal notification that a disposal hold has been lifted, provided no other disposal hold notice applies.
BUs maintain records of destruction and audit trails to evidence the authorisation and destruction of physical and electronic relevant records
Non-relevant records are only retained for as long as they have business value and are managed in accordance with the disposal control requirements set out in the Group Information Security Policy
Structured and Unstructured electronic relevant records are stored in a manner which ensures they can be effectively searched, identified and retrieved:

column1: (a) within a period required by any applicable legislative or regulatory requirements, or
